Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: METAL CATALYZED METHODS FOR THE PREPARATION OF ORGANOSILANES
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award from the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry supports the work of Professor Donald A. Watson of the University of Delaware. Professor Watson will develop catalytic methods for the introduction of silicon groups into unsaturated hydrocarbon frameworks using silyl-Heck-type reactions. These new reactions will allow for the conversion of a variety of simple and widely available alkenes and dienes into high value organosilanes, which have broad applications in chemical synthesis of both materials and biologically active molecules. In addition, Professor Watson will conduct experiments directed at understanding the mechanisms of silyl-Heck reactions, both to increase fundamental understanding of these processes and to aid in developing improved reaction conditions for these and related transformations.

The successful development of this research program is expected to have positive impact on a wide range of endeavors requiring the preparation of synthetic organic compounds, including pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and materials industries, as well as biological and chemical research. Professor Watson will also develop an integrated undergraduate research program directed at involving underrepresented minority students in cutting-edge chemical research. The goal of this educational component of his research is to provide encouragement and opportunities to students who have traditionally not participated in undergraduate research. This is expected to benefit participating students through increased connection to their field of study, development of mentoring relationships, and building of critical thinking and research skills, all of which are expected to increase retention of these students in sciences and provide critical training for future employment or graduate studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of CHE-1254360, "CAREER: Metal Catalyzed Methods For The Preparation Of Organosilanes", our group has been able to significantly contribute to the development of new chemical reactions involving the transition-metal catalyzed coupling of electrophilic silicon and boron reagents to carbon nucleophiles. In the area of silicon electrophiles, our initial studies funded by this award focused on the development of reactions joining silicon-electrophiles (silyl iodide and triflates) to alkenes, in a reaction analogous to the Heck-reaction. In so doing, we showed that these silyl-Heck reactions could be used to prepare vinyl silyl ethers (which are important substrates in organic synthesis), that intramolecular reactions are possible, and that the reactions can be catalyzed by nickel-complexes. Over the course of a series of papers, we rationally designed better ligands and transitional-metal complexes to be able to carry out allyl-silane and vinyl-silane forming silyl-Heck reaction much more efficiently than previously possible, and gained key insights in the how these reactions operate. In later work, we discovered that alkyl-organometallic nucleophiles could also be coupled to silicon-electrophiles using palladium-catalysis, and that these reactions allowed the preparation of difficult to make alpha-branched alkyl silanes. To accomplish these transformations, we also developed new catalysts to increase their efficiency. And importantly, we showed that these reactions could be carried out using alkyl magnesium bromide and chlorosilanes, both of which are commodity chemicals – making this a very practical process for organosilane synthesis. 

Finally, we were also able to show for the first time, that boron electrophiles can also participate in Heck-like reactions with alkenes. Over the series of two papers, we have now shown that both terminal monosubstituted alkenes, as well as more challenging 1,1- and 1,2- monosubstituted alkenes can be converted into highly valuable vinyl boronic esters using a boryl-Heck reaction. 

This work resulted in ten peer-reviewed scientific papers and one patent-applications. 

In terms of broader impacts, our work also allowed us to provide research opportunities to numerous at-risk early undergraduate students though the creation of the Research Experiences for Academic Chemists in Training (REACT) Program. Not only did this program provide training, context, motivation, and support for these student’s undergraduate studies, many of these students have gone on to PhD or MD studies after graduation.   

Overall, work from this award has not only developed new reactions to be able to prepare important chemical intermediates, but we have also uncovered fundamental new information about the types of reactions that are possible using transition-metal catalyzed cross-coupling approaches, and provided a model for how to retain and support at-risk undergraduates in STEM majors.
